awd_titl_txt: CHAI: Cyberinfrastructure Upgrades Supporting STEM Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the instructional, research, and development capacity at these institutions expands the opportunities for students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be locally relevant, and encourages a faculty community to look beyond the traditional classroom for intellectual and professional growth. This project aligns directly with that goal by strengthening the STEM cyberinfrastructure for instructional and research activities. The project aims to enhance cyberinfrastructure and cybersecurity necessary to facilitate development of the institution in STEM fields and for the protection of sensitive data. 

The project seeks to upgrade specific STEM IT resources at the institution to improve the resiliency and security of STEM operations, data management, teaching, and research enterprises. Improvements to ANC’s network and cybersecurity seeks to advance the college’s ability to implement advances in STEM instruction and research. The activities for developing STEM cyberinfrastructure will directly support current and future projects. Students will benefit from increased access to online resources and virtual courses. STEM research activities in environmental science and natural resources will be aided and enabled by advances in cyberinfrastructure at the institution.  Due to the inclusion of the library in the upgrade, the community served by the college will also benefit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project's goal was to refresh and update Aaniiih Nakoda College's campus network equipment to provide secure and easily maintainable network access in support of STEM research and education activities. Upgrades were designed to refresh the campus's out-of-date or end-of-life (EOL) equipment and intended to significantly improving management, usage monitoring, performance, security, and problem response time for the campus network. Specific project activities included replacing network switches with managed switches with 10 to 25GE backbone speed, configuring the network system to segment network and point of failure, replacing wireless network infrastructure with better coverage and management abilities, and replacing old CATV cables in some of the buildings and install patch panels where needed.

Over the course of the one-year project period, project personnel implemented these proposed activities by replacing old switches with HPE Aruba 6300s, replacing old wireless access points with Aruba 635s, installing patch panels in network closets in campus buildings, upgrading network equipment racks, and installing new CAT VI cable across campus. 

These project activities resulted in significant benefits. The replacement of network switches and wireless access points resulted in improvements related to back data haul between buildings and back to the network core. New switches allow for greater throughput and have four ports, which means they can handle larger data loads. Configuring all switches to vLANS has increased network speed and helped keep networks separated, thereby providing both the speed and security needed by college STEM faculty and students. 

The project achieved its intended impact by improving ANC's network management, usage monitoring, performance, security, and problem. This, in turn, removed network environment restrictions for STEM faculty, staff, and students and gave them improved access to the college's cyberinfrastructure and associated resources for STEM teaching, learning, and research. Impacts are especially evident for the college's two, NSF-funded Tribal Enterprise Advancement (TEA) Centers, the Aaniiih Nakoda Water Center and the Buffalo Research and Education Center.

The project is helping advance STEM research and education activities at ANC through better access to both campus-based and external information resources due to improved campus network infrastructure. Advances in network monitoring and automation have secured the campus infrastructure, improved operational efficiencies, and freed up IT staff time to focus on advanced networking support, including overall end-to-end network performance, which results in a more efficient and effective research and learning environment. 

Ultimately, the impact of the project is best articulated in relation to the ANC mission statement. By supporting these improvements in network performance, the project supports the STEM research and education activities that advance the college's delivery of high quality educational opportunities that promote individual and community development, support the maintenance and revitalization of Aaniiih and Nakoda lifeways, and prepare students to success in American technological society. 


Last Modified: 01/24/2025
Modified by: Scott R Friskics
